title-group.article-title: Management Buy-Outs from the Public Sector: Ownership Form and Incentive Issues

p.mixed-citation: See also Vickers and Yarrow (1988, pp. 45-77) for a more extensive treatment.

Yarrow (1989, p. 62) questions the statutory and organisational capacity of the Monopolies and Mergers Commission to police privatised (near-)monopolies. The directors of specific regulatory institutions — OFGAS, OFTEL, etc. — established to oversee particular industries appear to have considerable discretion in the interpretation of their roles.
The recent literature is reviewed in Cable (1988).
Some four years after privatisation British Telecom has proposed the externalisation of certain in-house service activities through semi-independent buy-outs.

These problems have been illustrated at the buy-out at City Centre Leisure, Westminster, where local authority-approval was necessary for such activities as marketing campaigns by the new venture (Wright, Normand and Robbie, 1990).

Cable (1988) points out that studies in Japan and Germany — countries in which bank-financing is more important than stock market funding — fail to reveal superiority for the M-form. It remains questionable whether an M-form's headquarters staff lose interest in 'empire-building' expenditures. The recent US experience with leveraged buy-outs (Jensen, 1989) indicates that some divisionalised firms engage in unnecessary staffing, particularly at the level of corporate HQ.
This evidence is reviewed in Stephen and Thompson (1988).

It is not entirely clear why the bankruptcy sanction is never applied to public enterprises. Of course, it might be difficult to allow statutory monopolies to fail, and even the possibility of such an outcome would raise the cost of capital to the public sector. However, the Republic of Ireland has removed the guarantee of support for its 'semi-state' enterprises (i.e. 'public corporations' in UK terms) and Irish Shipping did go into liquidation in 1987.

The bid by Hoylake for BAT in mid-1989 does indicate that size per se may be less of a defence than once thought. However, significant divestment may be needed to pay down debt quickly. Such 'unbundling' may be difficult in a state enterprise with a narrow spread of product areas, although break- up by, for example, régionalisation may be an option.

In November 1989 the Industry Secretary declined to use the Government's 'golden share' stake to block Ford's acquisition of the privatised Jaguar car company. Similarly, it has been suggested that a bid for BAA could be acceptable. However, there is no guarantee that a future government would be so permissive.
Yago (1990) reports improvements in employment in some years. He points out that employment comparisons are particularly difficult because buy-outs tend to occur among under-performing firms.

Most of the larger UK nationalised industries had accumulated considerable numbers of these peripheral activities. Their disposal left the 'core business' elements easier for the capital market to appraise.
A complete analysis of financier exits from MBOs is given in Chiplin, Wright and Robbie (1989).

As a crude test of how far actual privatisations followed these criteria, we took a sample of all primary flotations and all identifiable MBOs with a sale price (SIZE) exceeding £10 million. The businesses were classified as either PRODUCER (= 1) or consumer ( = 0) suppliers, to proxy product market instability, and classified as DIVESTMENT (= 1) or otherwise ( = 0), to proxy independent trading experience.
